content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling blue river, there lived a king named Midas.
King Midas was a kind and generous ruler, beloved by his people, but he had one great love that sometimes made him forget all else—gold.
King Midas adored gold more than anything in the world.
He loved the way it gleamed in the sunlight, the way it clinked when coins were counted, and the way it made everything it touched feel precious.
His palace was filled with golden treasures: golden goblets, golden plates, golden statues, and even a golden throne.
Yet, no matter how much gold he had, Midas always wanted more.
One day, as King Midas was walking through his royal gardens, he noticed a small, shimmering figure sitting beneath a rose bush.
The figure was a tiny, mischievous creature with pointed ears and a twinkle in his eye.
It was Silenus, a satyr and a friend of the god Dionysus.
"Good day, Your Majesty," Silenus said with a bow. "I seem to have lost my way.
Might you help me find my master, Dionysus?"  King Midas, who was always kind to strangers, smiled warmly.
"Of course, my dear fellow!
I shall have my servants search the kingdom for him at once."  True to his word, King Midas ordered his servants to find Dionysus, and before long, the god himself appeared in the palace gardens.
Dionysus was the god of wine, celebration, and joy, and he was overjoyed to see his old friend Silenus safe and sound.
"King Midas," Dionysus said, his voice rich and warm, "you have shown great kindness to my friend.
As a reward, I shall grant you one wish.
Whatever you desire, it shall be yours."  King Midas’s eyes sparkled with excitement. A wish!
This was his chance to have more gold than he had ever dreamed of.
Without hesitation, he said, "Oh, great Dionysus, I wish that everything I touch would turn to gold!"  Dionysus frowned slightly, for he knew the dangers of such a wish.
But he had promised, and so he nodded. "Very well, King Midas. Your wish is granted.
But remember, all gifts have their price."  With that, Dionysus vanished, leaving King Midas alone in the garden.
The king, eager to test his new power, reached out and touched a nearby rose.
To his delight, the petals turned to shimmering gold!
He laughed with joy and touched another rose, then a leaf, then a stone—each one transformed into gleaming gold.
Overcome with excitement, King Midas rushed back to his palace.
He touched the doors, the walls, the furniture—everything turned to gold!
His servants gasped in amazement as their king’s touch transformed the palace into a dazzling treasure trove.
But as the day wore on, King Midas began to feel hungry.
He sat down at his golden table and reached for a piece of bread.
The moment his fingers brushed the loaf, it turned to hard, cold gold.
He tried to take a sip of wine, but the liquid turned to gold as soon as it touched the goblet.
Panic crept into his heart. How would he eat? How would he drink?
Just then, his beloved daughter, Princess Marigold, ran into the room.
She had heard of her father’s magical gift and wanted to see it for herself.
"Father, it’s wonderful!" she cried, throwing her arms around him.
But the moment she touched him, her warm, living body turned into a lifeless golden statue.
King Midas’s heart shattered. He fell to his knees, sobbing. "What have I done?" he cried.

"I have lost everything that truly matters!"  In his despair, King Midas remembered Dionysus’s warning: *All gifts have their price.* He realized then that his love for gold had blinded him to the things that were truly precious—his daughter, his food, his happiness.
With tears streaming down his face, King Midas ran back to the garden where he had first met Dionysus.
He fell to his knees and begged, "Oh, great Dionysus, please take back my wish!
I do not want the golden touch anymore.
I only want my daughter back!"  Dionysus appeared before him, his expression sad but understanding.
"King Midas," he said, "you have learned a valuable lesson.
Gold cannot bring happiness, and true wealth lies in the love of others.
I shall take back your gift, but you must promise to use your wisdom wisely."  King Midas nodded eagerly.
"I promise, I promise!"  Dionysus instructed him to wash his hands in the river that flowed through the kingdom.
King Midas did as he was told, and as the water touched his skin, the golden touch faded away.
He rushed back to the palace and embraced his daughter, who was once again warm and alive.
From that day forward, King Midas cherished his daughter, his people, and the simple joys of life.
He still loved gold, but he no longer let it rule his heart.
And whenever he saw a golden treasure, he remembered the lesson he had learned: that the most precious things in life cannot be touched or held—they must be felt with the heart.
And so, King Midas lived happily ever after, wiser and kinder than before, with a heart full of love and a kingdom full of joy.
